intro: Rhynchospora candida var. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy white beakgrass, is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in North America. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like stems and small, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in summer. The variety pilosa is distinguished by its hairy foliage, which gives it a distinctive texture. This plant typically grows in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds. It plays an important role in wetland ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various invertebrates and birds.
